Movie: All Quiet on the Western Front

Review: Sam Mendes joins Roger Deakins once again to produce a gorgeous looking film with a great cast. Unfortunately he has little grasp of the subjects addressed in his screenplay. Supposedly set in 1981, Mendes films Micheal Ward as if he just stepped off a boat in the 1950s. The not-taking-meds trope is tired. Ward's character is given the task of explaining how awful racism is, while Olivia Colman can only speak truth in the throes of mental distress. Tricking ourselves…
Beautifully shot and well acted, this languid, wilfully blank drama offers a vice-versa scenario alongside a seemingly superfluous supblot.

Sam Mendes' WWI drama is immersive, emotionally engaged storytelling. Dean Charles Chapman and George Mackay are superb as the soldiers charged with a deadly, time-sensitive mission; the script allows moments of tenderness and reflection amid the peril. The other stars are Roger Deakins' photography, a masterclass in composition; and Thomas Newman's haunting score. Phenomenal work from all involved.

Rian Johnson's second Benoit Blanc mystery is an enjoyable romp, making good use of Daniel Craig and Janelle Monae in particular. A neat reversal and a convoluted denouement made this ideal holiday viewing.

Entertaining vampire horror with a blue collar teen perspective that sustains the plot through the first two acts. The final act is an admittedly fun 80s throwback that squanders the intriguing premise.
The cat and mouse element of this thriller is enjoyable but less interesting than the clash of morals between the protagonist and his pursuer.

Oliver Hermanus is a great choice of director for this material, as a portrait of how people carrying a burden conduct themselves. Kazuo Ishiguro's script is taught and precise, capturing the limits placed on language by decorum. At the heart of it is Bill Nighy's tremendous performance; a sad, belated awakening.
Park Chan-wook's noirish thriller is long but satisfying, with a nod to Hitchcock. Terrific performances and a dash of humour.
This film doesn't so much end as slip slide away...

Long but very likeable drama blending sporting camaraderie and gay relationships. Matt Carter directs, co-writes, edits, photographs and scores the film, proving to be a talent in each area. His achievement is to produce a film that has the kind of narrative elements usually reserved for straight dramas, completely paring away worthy social realism and victim tropes. The cast work well, there's chemistry between the two leads and a range of perspectives on offer.

Ti West's knowing pastiche boasts superb songs and sound design. The script nods to horror classics, while drawing parallels with porn and notions of aesthetic quality, while testing the audience's disgust threshold. A chilly, stately affair, as if Ari Aster directed Boogie Nights.

Guy Ritchie's second feature makes a simple story into a convoluted plot. A cast of familiar faces roll their tongues around the dialogue like they're chewing tobacco. Ritchie's signature tricksy cinematography suits the age of scrolling. Reasoble entertainment.
